{{Infobox institute |name = Bangladesh Forest Research Institute |image = |image_size = |image_alt = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |founder = |established = 1955 |mission = |focus = [[Forestry]] |president = |chairman = |head_label = |head = |faculty = |adjunct_faculty = |staff = 720 |key_people = Dr Khurshid Akher
(Director )(Current Charge) |budget = |endowment = |debt = |num_members = |subsidiaries = |owner = |non-profit_slogan = |former_name = East Pakistan Forest Research Laboratory |location = |city = [[Chattogram]] |state = [[Chattogram Division]] |province = |country = [[Bangladesh]] |coor = |address = |website = http://www.bfri.gov.bd/ |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Bangladesh Forest Research Institute (BFRI)''' is an institute for [[forestry]] research in Bangladesh, located at Sholashahar, [[Chattogram]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/nation/2017/09/22/216822/|title=BFRI campus: Haven for birds in Chittagong {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|website=www.dhakatribune.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-15}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-187199|title=Forest research institute totters|date=2011-05-26|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-12-15|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/opinion/society/protecting-what-ours-1473940|title=Protecting what is ours|date=2017-10-10|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-12-15|language=en}} == History == Bangladesh Forest Research Institute was established in 1955 as East Pakistan Forest Research Laboratory, BFRI works under the auspices of the [[Ministry of Environment and Forest (Bangladesh)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]]. Aside from its headquarter in Chattogram, BFRI has 21 Research Stations and Sub-Stations under five Field Divisions covering different forest types spread over eight [[Dendrology|dendrological]] regions of the country.{{cite news|title=Bangladesh Forest Research Institute|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Bangladesh_Forest_Research_Institute|accessdate=26 April 2014|newspaper=[[Banglapedia]]}} == Research divisions == * Forest Management Branch ** Silvicultural Research ** Silviculture Genetics ** Seed Orchard ** Mangrove Silviculture ** Plantation Trial Unit ** Minor Forest Products ** Forest Botany ** Forest Economics & Statistics ** Forest Inventory ** Soil Science ** Forest Protection * Forest Products Branch ** Wood Working & Timber Engineering ** Seasoning & Timber Physics ** Veneer & Composite Wood Products ** Wood Preservation ** Pulp and Paper ** Forest Chemistry == See also == * [[List of forest research institutes]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Coord|22.893|N|91.533|E|display=title}} [[Category:Forestry in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Research institutes established in 1955]] [[Category:Research institutes in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Forest research institutes]] [[Category:Government agencies of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Organisations based in Chittagong]] [[Category:1955 establishments in Pakistan]] {{forestry-stub}} {{Bangladesh-org-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Use in China */ Factually wrong sentence removed (2% of household use this form of fuel since 2001 as per a wikipedia article)
revision.text:
[[File:Charcoal Briquette.JPG|thumb|Some charcoal briquettes]] A '''briquette''' (or '''briquet''') is a compressed block of coal dust<ref>"briquette, n. 2.". ''Oxford English Dictionary''. 2nd ed. 2009. Print.</ref> or other [[combustible]] [[biomass]] material such as charcoal, sawdust, wood chips,<ref>"briquette." ''American HeritageÂ® Dictionary of the English Language'', 5th. ed.. 2011. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing Company 15 Mar. 2015 http://www.thefreedictionary.com/briquette</ref> peat, or paper used for [[fuel]] and kindling to start a [[Combustion|fire]]. The term comes from the French language and is related to ''brick''.
== Coal briquettes == [[File:Braunkohle_als_Hausbrand.jpg|thumb|Coal briquette]] [[File:Rekord_Brikett.jpg|thumb|Coal briquette]] [[Coal]] briquettes have long been produced as a means of using up '[[small coal]]', the finely broken coal inevitably produced during the [[coal mining|mining]] process. Otherwise this is difficult to burn as it is both hard to arrange adequate airflow through a fire of these small pieces, also it tended to be drawn up and out of the chimney by the [[chimney draught|draught]], giving visible black smoke.
The first briquettes were known as [[culm (coal)|culm]] and were hand-moulded with a little wet [[clay]] as a binder. These could be difficult to burn efficiently, as the unburned clay produced a large ash content, blocking airflow through a grate.
With Victorian developments in engineering, particularly the [[hydraulic press]], it became possible to produce machine-made briquettes with minimal binder content. A [[tar]] or [[pitch (resin)|pitch]] binder was used, obtained first from [[town gas|gas making]] and later from petrochemical sources. These binders burned away completely, making it a low-ash fuel. A proprietary brand of briquettes from the [[South Wales coalfield]] was Phurnacite, developed by [[Powell Duffryn]].<ref name="Phurnacite, Briquettes" >{{Cite web |title=The Phurnacite plant, the briquette |website=Aberdare Online |url=http://www.aberdareonline.co.uk/history/phurnacite-plant-abercwmboi/phurnacite-plant-briquette }}</ref> These were intended to emulate a high-quality [[anthracite]] coal, such as that from the [[Cynheidre Colliery|Cynheidre]] measures. This involved blending a mixture of coals from different grades and colliery sources. Phurnacite used the following mix:<ref name="Phurnacite, Briquettes" /> * [[Bituminous coal]], 25% * [[Steam coal]], 45% * Dry steam coal, 22% * Pitch, 8%
Early briquettes were large and brick-shaped. They could be stacked, or even built into walls. The [[Nimrod Expedition|Antarctic expedition]]s of both [[Ernest Shackleton|Shackleton]] and [[Robert Falcon Scott|Scott]] took large quantities of these briquettes with them and used them to build pony stables. As the ponies were eaten, as planned, for food, the stables could be dismantled and used for fuel.<ref name="Phurnacite, Briquettes" /> Phurnacite briquettes later adopted a squared oval shape. This regular shape packed well as a good firebed, with plentiful airflow. They are also easy to mechanically feed, allowing the development of automatically controlled heating boilers that could run for days without human intervention.
{{clear}}
== Charcoal briquettes == [[File:BurningOgatan(JapaneseBriquetteCharcoal).theora.ogv|thumb|Burning ''Ogatan'']] Charcoal briquettes sold for cooking food can include:<ref>Joe O'Connell. [http://old.cbbqa.org/wood/Kingsford.html Kingsford Brand Charcoal Ingredients]. California Barbecue Association website. Retrieved 11 May 2007.</ref><ref>[http://virtualweberbullet.com/charcoal.html All About Charcoal]. virtualweberbullet.com. Retrieved May 11, 2007.</ref> * [[charcoal|Wood charcoal]] (fuel) * [[Lignite|Lignite coal]] (fuel) * [[Anthracite|Anthracite coal]] (fuel) * [[Limestone]] (ash colourant) * [[Starch]] (binder) * [[Borax]] (release agent) * [[Sodium nitrate]] (accelerant) * [[Sawdust]] * [[Wax#Petroleum derived waxes|Wax]] (some brands: binder, accelerant, ignition facilitator). * [[Chaff]] (rice chaff and peanut chaff)
Some briquettes are compressed and dried [[lignite|brown coal]] extruded into hard blocks. This is a common technique for [[coal rank|low rank]] coals. They are typically dried to 12-18% moisture, and are primarily used in household and industry.
== East-Asian briquettes ==
Home made charcoal briquettes (called ''[[:ja:ç­å£|Tadon]]'') were found after charcoal production in Japanese history. In the [[Edo period]], polysaccharide extracted from [[red algae]] was widely used as a binder. After the imports of steam engines in the [[Meiji period]], coal and clay became major ingredients of Japanese briquettes. These briquettes,''[[:ja:ç·´ç­|Rentan]]'' and ''[[:ja:è±ç­|Mametan]]'' , were exported to [[China]] and [[Korea]]. Today, coal briquettes are avoided for their [[sulfur oxide]] emission. Charcoal briquettes are still used for traditional or outdoor cooking. Woody flakes such as [[sawdust]] or coffee dust are major ingredients of modern mass-consumed briquettes (e.g. ''[[:ja:ãªã¬ç­|Ogatan]]'').
<gallery> File:Japanese_RoundStove_Charcoal.JPG|Quick Grill Briquette File:Japanese_Rentan_with_FireStarter.JPG|''[[Yeontan]]'', Korean Coal briquette File:Japanese_CoalBriquettes_Mametan_01.jpg|''Mametan'', Japanese Coal briquettes File:Ogatan(JapaneseBriquetteCharcoal).jpg|''Ogatan'', Japanese charcoal briquettes made from sawdust. File:Ogatan_solid.JPG|Solid type ''Ogatan'' File:Japanese_HighCaloTan.JPG|''High calo tan'', Made from [[coffee]] dust. File:Edo_personal_stove.JPG|''Tadon'' and ''[[Shichirin]]'' </gallery>
{{clear}}
==Use in China== [[File:Fuel cylinders 01.jpg|thumb|150px|Fuel briquettes, called ''mei'' (coal ç ¤), sold throughout [[People's Republic of China|China]]]] Throughout China, cylindrical briquettes, called ''"fÄng wÅ mÃ©i"'' (beehive coal èçª©ç ¤ / èçªç ¤) or ''"Mei"'' (coal ç ¤) or ''"liÃ n tÃ n"'' (kneaded coal ç·´ç­ / ç»ç­), are used in purpose-built cookers.
The origin of ''"Mei"'' is ''"[[:ja:ç·´ç­|Rentan]]"'' (kneaded coal ç·´ç­) of Japan. ''Rentan'' was invented in Japan in the 19th century, and spread to [[Manchukuo]], Korea and China in the first half of the 20th century. There were many ''Rentan'' factories in Manchukuo and [[Pyongyang]]. Although ''Rentan'' went out of use in Japan after the 1970s, it is still popular in China and [[Vietnam]] (''"than"'' coal).
The cookers are simple, ceramic vessels with metal exteriors. Two types are made: the single, or triple briquette type, the latter holding the briquettes together side by side. These cookers can accommodate a double stack of cylinders. A small fire of tinder is started, upon which the cylinder(s) is placed. When a cylinder is spent, another cylinder is placed on top using special tongs, with the one below igniting it. The fire can be maintained by swapping spent cylinders for fresh ones, and retaining a still-glowing spent cylinder.
Each cylinder lasts for over an hour. These cookers are used to cook, or simmer, pots of tea, eggs, soups, stews, etc. The cylinders are delivered, usually by cart, to businesses, and are very inexpensive.
{{clear}}
==Peat briquettes== [[File:Bsc_puzolana.jpg|thumb|upright|Peat block]] In [[Ireland]], [[peat]] briquettes are a common type of [[solid fuel]], largely replacing [[peat cutting|sod]]s of raw peat as a domestic fuel. These briquettes consist of shredded peat, compressed to form a virtually smokeless, slow-burning, easily stored and transported fuel. Although often used as the sole fuel for a fire, they are also used to quickly and easily light a coal fire.
{{clear}}
==Biomass briquettes== [[File:Straw-hay-briquettes.jpg|thumb|Straw or hay briquettes]] [[File:Heubrikett.jpg|thumb|Biomass briquette]] {{main|Biomass briquettes}} Biomass briquettes are made from agricultural waste and are a replacement for [[fossil fuel]]s such as oil or coal, and can be used to heat boilers in manufacturing plants, and also have applications in [[developing country|developing countries]]. Biomass briquettes are a renewable source of energy and avoid adding fossil carbon to the atmosphere.{{clarify|date=December 2016}}
A number of companies in India have switched from furnace oil to biomass briquettes to save costs on boiler fuels. The use of biomass briquettes is predominant in the southern parts of India, where coal and furnace oil are being replaced by biomass briquettes. A number of units in [[Maharashtra]] (India) are also using biomass briquettes as boiler fuel. Use of biomass briquettes can earn Carbon Credits for reducing emissions in the atmosphere. Lanxess India and a few other large companies are supposedly using biomass briquettes for earning Carbon Credits by switching their boiler fuel. Biomass briquettes also provide more calorific value/kg and save around 30-40 percent of boiler fuel costs.
A popular biomass briquette emerging in developed countries takes a waste produce such as sawdust, compresses it and then extrudes it to make a reconstituted log that can replace firewood. It is a similar process to forming a wood pellet but on a larger scale. There are no binders involved in this process. The natural [[lignin]] in the wood binds the particles of wood together to form a solid. Burning a wood briquette is far more efficient than burning firewood. Moisture content of a briquette can be as low as 4%, whereas green firewood may be as high as 65%.
For example, parameters of fuel briquettes made by [[extrusion]] from sawdust in [[Ukraine]]:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Parameter !! Value |- | Briquette density, t/mÂ³ || 1.0-1.2 |- | [[Heat content]], MJ/kg || 19.3-20.5 |- | Ash content, % || 0.5-1.5 |} <small>(MJ = Megajoules. 3.6 MJ equals 1 kWh.)</small>
The extrusion production technology of briquettes is the process of extrusion screw wastes (straw, sunflower husks, buckwheat, etc.) or finely shredded wood waste (sawdust) under high pressure when heated from {{convert|160|to|350|C}}. As shown in the table above the quality of such briquets, especially heat content, is much higher comparing with other methods like using piston presses.
Sawdust briquettes have developed over time with two distinct types: those with holes through the centre, and those that are solid. Both types are classified as briquettes but are formed using different techniques. A solid briquette is manufactured using a piston press that compresses sandwiched layers of sawdust together. Briquettes with a hole are produced with a screw press. The hole is from the screw thread passing through the centre, but it also increases the surface area of the log and aids efficient [[combustion]].
==Paper briquettes== Paper briquettes are the byproduct of a briquettor, which compresses shredded paper material into a small cylindrical form. Briquettors are often sold as add-on systems to existing disintegrator or rotary knife mill shredding systems. The NSA has a maximum particle size regulation for shredded paper material that is passed through a disintegrator or rotary knife mill, which typically does not exceed 1/8â square.<ref>[http://www.nsa.gov/ia/_files/Government/MDG/NSA_CSS_EPL_02_02_P.pdf NSA Standards for Disintegrators]</ref> This means that material exiting a disintegrator is the appropriate size for compression into paper briquettes, as opposed to strip-cut shredders which produce long sheets of paper.
After being processed through the disintegrator, paper particles are typically passed through an air system to remove dust and unwanted magnetic materials before being sent into the briquettor. The air system may also be responsible for regulating moisture content in the waste particles, as briquetting works optimally within a certain range of moisture. Studies have shown that the optimal moisture percentage for shredded particles is 18% for paper and 22% for wheat straw.<ref>Physical properties of briquettes from waste paper and wheat straw mixtures [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0196890498001113]</ref>
=== Environmental impact === Briquetted paper has many notable benefits, many of which minimize the impact of the paper waste generated by a shredding system. Several manufactures claim up to 90% volume reduction of briquetted paper waste versus traditional shredding. Decreasing the volume of shredded waste allows it to be transported and stored more efficiently, reducing the cost and fuel required in the disposal process.
In addition to the cost savings associated with reducing the volume of waste, paper briquettes are more useful in paper mills to create recycled paper than uncompressed shredded material. Compressed briquettes can also be used as a fuel for starting fires or as an insulating material.
==Safety== Charcoal burners should not be used in enclosed environments to heat homes, as [[Carbon monoxide poisoning]] can be fatal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|title=Man died from carbon monoxide poisoning after using 'heat beads' in Greystanes home|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Biomass Cook Stoves]] * [[Energy in Victoria]] * [[Wood briquette]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Briquettes}} {{Wikisource1911Enc|Briquette}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140429200002/http://www.indycarbon.com/coconut-shell-charcoal-briquettes.htm Coconut Shell Charcoal Briquettes] *[http://www.madehow.com/Volume-4/Charcoal-Briquette.html How charcoal briquettes are made.] *[http://bioenergylists.org/stovesdoc/Stanley/BriqGassstove.htm Holey Briquette Gassifier Stove Development], Richard Stanley, Kobus Venter 14 August 2003 on ''BioEnergy Lists''. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160305210614/http://thesustainablevillage.com/sr2003/archive/2003/pre-conf/stanley.html Briquetting: An Answer to Desertification, Health Problems, Unemployment and Reforestation in Developing Communities] - summary of 2003 seminar.

revision.text:
In the [[solid-state physics]] of [[semiconductor]]s, '''carrier generation''' and '''radiative recombination''' are processes by which mobile [[charge carrier]]s ([[electron]]s and [[electron hole]]s) are created and eliminated. Carrier generation and recombination processes are fundamental to the operation of many [[optoelectronics|optoelectronic]] [[semiconductor device]]s, such as [[photodiode]]s, [[Light-emitting diode|LED]]s and [[laser diode]]s. They are also critical to a full analysis of [[p-n junction]] devices such as [[BJT]]s and p-n junction [[diode]]s.
The '''electronâhole pair''' is the fundamental unit of generation and recombination, corresponding to an electron transitioning between the valence band and the conduction band where generation of electron is a transition from the valence band to the conduction band and recombination leads to a reverse transition.
==Band structure== Like other solids, semiconductor materials have an [[electronic band structure]] determined by the crystal properties of the material. The actual energy distribution among the electrons is described by the [[Fermi level]] and the [[temperature]] of the electrons. At [[absolute zero]] temperature, all of the electrons have energy below the Fermi level; but at non-zero temperatures the energy levels are filled following a Boltzmann distribution.
[[Image:Electronic band diagram.svg|thumb|375px|Electronic band structure of a semiconductor material.]]In undoped semiconductors the Fermi level lies in the middle of a ''forbidden band'' or [[band gap]] between two ''allowed bands'' called the ''[[valence band]]'' and the ''[[conduction band]]''. The valence band, immediately below the forbidden band, is normally very nearly completely occupied. The conduction band, above the Fermi level, is normally nearly completely empty. Because the valence band is so nearly full, its electrons are not mobile, and cannot flow as electric current.
However, if an electron in the valence band acquires enough energy to reach the conduction band, it can flow freely among the nearly empty conduction band energy states. Furthermore, it will also leave behind an electron hole that can flow as current exactly like a physical charged particle. Carrier ''generation'' describes processes by which electrons gain energy and move from the valence band to the conduction band, producing two mobile carriers; while ''recombination'' describes processes by which a conduction band electron loses energy and re-occupies the energy state of an electron hole in the valence band.
In a material at [[thermal equilibrium]] generation and recombination are balanced, so that the net [[charge carrier]] density remains constant. The equilibrium carrier density that results from the balance of these interactions is predicted by [[thermodynamics]]. The resulting probability of occupation of energy states in each energy band is given by [[FermiâDirac statistics]].
===Generation and recombination processes=== Carrier generation and recombination occur when an [[electron]] makes transition from the valence band to conduction band in a semiconductor, as a result of interaction with other [[electron]]s, [[Electron hole|holes]], [[photon]]s, or the [[Phonon|vibrating crystal lattice itself]]. These processes must conserve both quantized energy and momentum, and the [[Phonon|vibrating lattice]] plays a large role in conserving momentum as, in collisions, [[photon]]s can transfer very little momentum in relation to their energy.
Recombination and generation are always happening in semiconductors, both optically and thermally, and their rates are in balance at equilibrium. The product of the electron and hole densities (<math>n</math> and <math>p</math>) is a constant <math>(n_o p_o=n_i^2)</math> '''at equilibrium''', maintained by recombination and generation occurring at equal rates. When there is a surplus of carriers (i.e., <math>n p>n_i^2</math>), the rate of recombination becomes greater than the rate of generation, driving the system back towards equilibrium. Likewise, when there is a deficit of carriers (i.e., <math>n p<n_i^2</math>), the generation rate becomes greater than the recombination rate, again driving the system back towards equilibrium.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1109/LED.2014.2345058 | volume=35 | issue=10 | title=Optically Excited MOS-Capacitor for Recombination Lifetime Measurement | year=2014 | journal=IEEE Electron Device Letters | pages=986â988 | last1 = Elhami Khorasani | first1 = Arash | last2 = Schroder | first2 = Dieter K. | last3 = Alford | first3 = T. L.| bibcode=2014IEDL...35..986K }}</ref> As the electron moves from one energy band to another, the energy and momentum that it has lost or gained must go to or come from the other particles involved in the process (e.g. [[photon]]s, [[electron]], or the [[Phonon|system of vibrating lattice atoms]]). The following models are used to describe generation and recombination, depending on which particles are involved in the process.
[[File:diffusion center.gif|thumb|350px|right|The following image shows change in excess carriers being generated (green:electrons and purple:holes) with increasing light intensity (Generation rate /cm3) at the center of an intrinsic semiconductor bar. Electrons have higher diffusion constant than holes leading to fewer excess electrons at the center as compared to holes.]]
=== ShockleyâReadâHall (SRH) process === In ''Shockley-Read-Hall recombination'', also called ''trap-assisted recombination'', the electron in transition between bands passes through a new energy state (localized state) created within the band gap by an impurity in the lattice; such energy states are called [[deep-level trap]]s. The localized state can absorb differences in [[momentum]] between the carriers, and so this process is the dominant generation and recombination process in [[silicon]] and other [[direct and indirect band gaps|indirect bandgap]] materials. It can also dominate in [[direct and indirect band gaps|direct bandgap]] materials under conditions of very low [[charge carrier density|carrier densities]] (very low level injection). The energy is exchanged in the form of lattice vibration, a [[phonon]] exchanging thermal energy with the material. The process is named after [[William Shockley]], [[William Thornton Read]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shockley|first1=W.|last2=Read|first2=W. T.|title=Statistics of the Recombinations of Holes and Electrons|journal=Physical Review|date=1 September 1952|volume=87|issue=5|pages=835â842|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.87.835|bibcode = 1952PhRv...87..835S }}</ref> and [[Robert N. Hall]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hall|first1=R.N.|title=Germanium rectifier characteristics|journal=Physical Review|date=1951|volume=83|issue=1|page=228}}</ref>
=== Radiative recombination === During ''radiative recombination'', a form of [[spontaneous emission]], a [[photon]] is emitted with the wavelength corresponding to the energy released. This effect is the basis of [[light-emitting diode|LEDs]]. Because the photon carries relatively little [[momentum]], radiative recombination is significant only in [[direct bandgap]] materials.
When photons are present in the material, they can either be [[absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorbed]], generating a pair of free carriers, or they can ''stimulate'' a recombination event, resulting in a generated photon with similar properties to the one responsible for the event. Absorption is the active process in [[photodiode]]s, [[solar cell]]s, and other semiconductor [[photodetector]]s, while [[stimulated emission]] is responsible for laser action in [[laser diode]]s.
In thermal equilibrium the radiative recombination <math>R_r</math> and thermal generation rate <math>G_0</math> equal each other<ref name="sheng-p140">{{Cite book|last=|first=|date=2006|editor-last=Li|editor-first=Sheng S.|title=Semiconductor Physical Electronics|journal=|language=en-gb|volume=|pages=140|doi=10.1007/0-387-37766-2|isbn=978-0-387-28893-2|url=http://cds.cern.ch/record/1066014|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> :<math> R_r = G_0 = B_r n_0 p_0 = B_r n_i^2 </math> where <math>B_r</math> is called the radiative capture probability and <math>n_i</math> the intrinsic carrier density.
Under steady-state conditions the radiative recombination rate <math>r_r</math> and resulting net recombination rate <math>U_r</math> are<ref name="sheng-p140"/> :<math> r_r = B_r n p \,, \quad U_r = r_r-G_0 = B_r \left( np-n_i^2 \right) </math> where the carrier densities <math>n,p</math> are made up of equilibrium <math>n_0, p_0</math> and excess densities <math>\Delta n, \Delta p</math> :<math> n = n_0 + \Delta n \,, \quad p = p_0 + \Delta p \,. </math> The radiative lifetime <math>\tau_r</math> is given by<ref name="sheng-p140"/> :<math> \tau_r = \frac{\Delta n}{U_r} = \frac{1}{B_r \left( n_0 + p_0 + \Delta n \right)} \,. </math>
=== Auger recombination === In ''Auger recombination'' the energy is given to a third carrier, which is excited to a higher energy level without moving to another energy band. After the interaction, the third carrier normally loses its excess energy to thermal vibrations. Since this process is a three-particle interaction, it is normally only significant in non-equilibrium conditions when the carrier density is very high. The [[Auger effect]] process is not easily produced, because the third particle would have to begin the process in the unstable high-energy state.
In thermal equilibrium the Auger recombination <math>R_A</math> and thermal generation rate <math>G_0</math> equal each other<ref name="sheng-p143">{{Cite book|last=|first=|date=2006|editor-last=Li|editor-first=Sheng S.|title=Semiconductor Physical Electronics|journal=|language=en-gb|volume=|pages=143|doi=10.1007/0-387-37766-2|isbn=978-0-387-28893-2|url=http://cds.cern.ch/record/1066014|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> :<math> R_A = G_0 = C_n n_0^2 p_0 + C_p n_0 p_0^2 </math> where <math>C_n,C_p</math> are the Auger capture probabilities.
The non-equilibrium Auger recombination rate <math>r_A</math> and resulting net recombination rate <math>U_A</math> under steady-state conditions are<ref name="sheng-p143"/> :<math> r_A = C_n n^2 p + C_p n p^2 \,, \quad U_A = r_A-G_0 = C_n \left( n^2p-n_0^2 p_0 \right) + C_p \left( np^2- n_0 p_0^2 \right) \,. </math>
The Auger lifetime <math>\tau_A</math> is given by<ref>{{Cite book|last=|first=|date=2006|editor-last=Li|editor-first=Sheng S.|title=Semiconductor Physical Electronics|journal=|language=en-gb|volume=|pages=144|doi=10.1007/0-387-37766-2|isbn=978-0-387-28893-2|url=http://cds.cern.ch/record/1066014|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> :<math> \tau_A = \frac{\Delta n}{U_A} = \frac{1}{ n^2C_n + 2n_i^2(C_n+C_p) +p^2C_p } \,. </math>
==== Auger recombination in LEDs ==== The mechanism causing [[Light-emitting diode#Efficiency droop|LED efficiency droop]] was identified in 2007 as Auger recombination, which met with a mixed reaction.<ref name=stevenson>Stevenson, Richard (August 2009) [http://www.spectrum.ieee.org/semiconductors/optoelectronics/the-leds-dark-secret The LEDâs Dark Secret: Solid-state lighting won't supplant the lightbulb until it can overcome the mysterious malady known as droop]. IEEE Spectrum</ref> In 2013, an experimental study claimed to have identified Auger recombination as the cause of efficiency droop.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Justin Iveland |author2=Lucio Martinelli |author3=Jacques Peretti |author4=James S. Speck |author5=Claude Weisbuch. |title=Cause of LED Efficiency Droop Finally Revealed|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/04/130423102328.htm|website=Physical Review Letters, 2013|publisher=Science Daily|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref> However, it remains disputed whether the amount of Auger loss found in this study is sufficient to explain the droop. Other frequently quoted evidence against Auger as the main droop causing mechanism is the low-temperature dependence of this mechanism which is opposite to that found for the drop.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * N.W. Ashcroft and N.D. Mermin, ''Solid State Physics'', Brooks Cole, 1976
==External links== * [http://www.pvlighthouse.com.au/calculators/Recombination%20calculator/Recombination%20calculator.aspx PV Lighthouse Recombination Calculator] * [http://www.pvlighthouse.com.au/calculators/Band%20gap%20calculator/Band%20gap%20calculator.aspx PV Lighthouse Band Gap Calculator]
[[Category:Condensed matter physics]] [[Category:Optoelectronics]] [[Category:Charge carriers]]

revision.comment: Alter: title. Add: website. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox winter storm|name=Christmas 1994 Nor'easter |image location=1994122318GOES7vis.png |image name=Visible image of the pair of cyclones interacting near the Eastern Seaboard from 1 p.m. [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] (08:00 UTC) on December 23, 1994 |alt=A satellite image of the eastern United States and western Caribbean Sea, depicting two large storms. |stormtype=[[Nor'easter]] |date formed=December 22, 1994 |date dissipated=December 26, 1994 |maximum amount=No snow or ice reported |pressure=970 [[mbar]] ([[Hectopascal|hPa]]) |total damages (USD)=> $21 million 1994 USD |total fatalities=2 |areas affected=[[East Coast of the United States]] }} The '''Christmas 1994 nor'easter''' was an intense [[cyclone]] along the [[East Coast of the United States]] and [[Atlantic Canada]]. It developed from an area of [[low-pressure area|low pressure]] in the southeast [[Gulf of Mexico]] near the [[Florida Keys]], and moved across the state of [[Florida]]. As it entered the warm waters of the [[Gulf Stream]] in the Atlantic Ocean, it began to rapidly intensify, exhibiting traits of a [[tropical cyclone|tropical system]], including the formation of an [[eye (cyclone)|eye]]. It attained a pressure of 970 [[Bar (unit)|millibars]] on December 23 and 24, and after moving northward, it came ashore near New York City on Christmas Eve. Because of the uncertain nature of the storm, the [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC) did not classify it as a tropical cyclone.
Heavy rain from the developing storm contributed to significant flooding in [[South Carolina]]. Much of the rest of the East Coast was affected by high winds, coastal flooding, and [[beach erosion]]. [[New York (state)|New York]] State and [[New England]] bore the brunt of the storm; damage was extensive on [[Long Island]], and in [[Connecticut]], 130,000 households lost electric power during the storm. Widespread damage and power outages also occurred throughout [[Rhode Island]] and [[Massachusetts]], where the storm generated {{convert|30|ft|m|adj=on}} waves along the coast. Because of the warm weather pattern that contributed to the storm's development, precipitation was limited to rain. Two people were killed, and damage amounted to at least $21 million.
==Meteorological history== [[File:Nor'easter 1994-12-21 weather map.jpg|left|thumb|A map of the developing storm on December 21|alt=A map depicting a storm near Florida]] The storm originated in an upper-level [[low-pressure area|low pressure system]] that moved southeastward from the central [[Great Plains]] into the [[Deep South]] of the United States. After reaching the southeast Gulf of Mexico, the disturbance underwent [[cyclogenesis]], and the resultant system moved through Florida on December 22 in response to an approaching [[Trough (meteorology)|trough]].<ref name="maps"/> [[National Hurricane Center]] forecaster Jack Beven noted that "as it moved out into the Bahamas, it appeared to take on the characteristics of a tropical storm."<ref name="met"/> The uncertain nature of the storm prevented the NHC from issuing advisories on it, and forecasters lacked sufficient data to fully assess the cyclone for potential [[tropical cyclone|tropical characteristics]]. The same trough that pushed the storm across Florida had moved to the north, allowing for [[high-pressure area|high pressure]] to develop in the upper levels of the atmosphere.<ref name="met">{{cite web|author=Robert Henson|title=Weatherwise, December 1995 vol. 48 # 6|year=1995|website=Hurricanes in disguise|publisher=Weatheranswer.com|accessdate=2008-10-18|url=http://www.weatheranswer.com/public/Hybrids_.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref>
Deemed a "hybrid storm", the cyclone rapidly intensified in warm waters of up to {{convert|80|F|C}} from the Gulf Stream combined with a cold air mass over the United States.<ref name="USA Today">{{cite news|author=Chris Cappella|title=1991's 'perfect storm' a hybrid hurricane|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=2008-10-19|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/wdisguis.htm | date=2005-05-17}}</ref> The system continued to rapidly intensify while moving within the Gulf Stream; it developed central [[atmospheric convection|convection]], an unusual trait for an [[extratropical cyclone]], and at one point exhibited an [[eye (cyclone)|eye]].<ref name="maps"/> Despite these indications of tropical characteristics, "There was no front associated with it and it had a warm core, but the radius of maximum winds was more than {{convert|150|nmi|mi km|lk=on}}, so under the standard NHC criteria it didn't qualify as a tropical storm."<ref name="met"/> On December 23 and 24, the [[nor'easter]] intensified to attain a barometric pressure of {{convert|970|mb|inHg|abbr=on}}.<ref name="met"/> An upper-level low pressure system that developed behind the storm began to intensify and grew to be larger in size than the original disturbance. In an interaction known as the [[Fujiwhara effect]], the broad circulation of the secondary low swung the primary nor'easter northwestward towards southern New York and New England.<ref name="USA Today"/> The original low passed along the south shore of [[Long Island]], and made landfall near New York City on December 24.<ref name="LI"/> Subsequently, it moved over southeastern [[New York State]].<ref name="Hudson Valley"/> On December 25, the system began to rapidly weaken as it moved towards [[Nova Scotia]], before the pair of low pressure systems moved out to sea in tandem in the early hours of December 26.<ref name="maps">{{cite web|publisher=[[U.S. Department of Commerce]]|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/dwm/1994/19941219-19941225.djvu |title=Daily Weather Maps: December 19â25, 1994|accessdate=2006-11-19}}</ref>
==Effects==
===Southeast United States=== In South Carolina, flooding associated with the cyclone was considered to be the worst since 1943.<ref name="worst">{{cite web|author=|title=Heavy rains/flooding Event Report Details for South Carolina|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~231953|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030039/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~231953|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Over {{convert|5|in|mm}} of rainfall was reported, while winds brought down trees and ripped awnings. In addition, the coast suffered the effects of [[beach erosion]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Thunderstorm Winds Event Report Details for South Carolina|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232108|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030111/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232108|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Thousands of electric customers in the state lost power.<ref>{{cite news|title=Winds hit Carolinas|date=December 24, 1994|department=A|page=10|work=The Atlanta Constitution}}</ref> As a result of the heavy rainfall, several dams became overwhelmed by rising waters.<ref name="worst"/> Extensive flooding of roads and highways was reported, many of which were closed as a result.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Heavy rains/flooding Event Report Details for South Carolina (2)|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232468|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030232/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232468|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Up to {{convert|3|ft|m}} of water flooded some homes in the region.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Heavy rains/flooding Event Report Details for South Carolina (3)|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232279|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030257/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232279|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Approximately 300 people in [[Florence County, South Carolina|Florence County]] were forced to evacuate because of the flooding, and at least 200 homes were damaged.<ref name="SC damage total NCDC">{{cite web|author=|title=Heavy rains/flooding Event Report Details for South Carolina (4)|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232075|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030316/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~232075|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Two deaths were reported in the state. One woman was killed when her vehicle [[Hydroplaning (tires)|hydroplaned]] and struck a tree, and another person drowned after her car was struck by another vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff Writer|title=Rainstorm Clobbers East Coast; 2 Reported Dead, Electricity Out|year=1994|publisher=''The Washington Post''|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-925373.html}}</ref> Total damage in South Carolina amounted to at least $4 million.<ref name="SC damage total NCDC"/> [[Image:19941224surfacemap.gif|thumb|right|Weather map of the interacting pair of [[cyclone]]s during the morning of December 24, 1994|alt=A map depicting two large storms near the United States]]
Strong winds occurred along the North Carolina coast. Diamond Shoals reported sustained winds of {{convert|45|mph|km/h}}, and offshore, winds gusted to {{convert|65|mph|km/h}}. On [[Wrightsville Beach, North Carolina|Wrightsville Beach]], rough surf eroded an {{convert|8|ft|m|adj=on}} ledge into the beach. On [[Carolina Beach]], dunes were breached and some roads, including portions of [[North Carolina Highway 12]], were closed.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Flooding Event Record Details for North Carolina|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-19|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~220911|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025720/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~220911|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
===Mid-Atlantic=== As the primary storm entered New England, the secondary low produced minor coastal flooding in the [[Tidewater region of Virginia]] on December 23. Winds of {{convert|35|to|45|mph|km/h}} and tides to {{convert|1|to|3|ft|m}} above normal were reported. In [[Sandbridge, Virginia Beach, Virginia]], a beachfront home collapsed into the sea. Several roads throughout the region suffered minor flooding.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Coastal Flooding Event Record Details for Virginia|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-19|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~244848|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025743/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~244848|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Strong winds resulting from the tight pressure gradient between the nor'easter and an area of high pressure located over the United States brought down a few utility poles, which sparked a [[brush fire]] on December 24. The fire, quickly spread by the wind, burned a field. The winds brought down several trees.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=High Wind Event Record Details for Virginia|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-19|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~244849|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025902/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~244849|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
Damage was light in [[Maryland]]. Some [[sand dunes]] and wooden structures were damaged, and above-normal tides occurred.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Coastal Flooding Event Record Details for Maryland|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-19|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208712|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025955/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208712|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> In [[New Jersey]], high winds caused power outages and knocked down trees and power lines.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Marlowe|title=Storm Causes Power Outages for Thousands in N.J|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-22610668.html|publisher=''The Record''}}</ref> Minor coastal flooding of streets and houses was reported. Otherwise, damage in the state was minor.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|author=Dennis Hevesi|title=Storms Darken Holiday In Connecticut and on L.I.|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02EFDB163BF936A15751C1A962958260 | date=1994-12-25}}</ref>
The storm brought heavy rainfall and high winds to New York State and New York City on December 23 and 24.<ref name="weather">{{cite web|author=|title=Mild Weather Continues|publisher=Cornell University|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www.nrcc.cornell.edu/climate/Impacts_12-94.html| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070611034722/http://www.nrcc.cornell.edu/climate/Impacts_12-94.html| archivedate = June 11, 2007}}</ref> Gusts of {{convert|60|to|80|mph}} downed hundreds of trees and many power lines on [[Long Island]]. Several homes, in addition to many cars, sustained damage. Roughly 112,000 [[Long Island Lighting Company]] customers experienced power outages at some point during the storm.<ref name="LI">{{cite web|author=|title=High Wind Event Record Details for New York|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219820|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030518/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219820|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> As the cyclone progressed northward into New York State, high winds occurred in the [[Hudson Valley]] region. Throughout [[Columbia County, New York|Columbia]], [[Ulster County, New York|Ulster]] and [[Rensselaer County, New York|Rensselaer]] Counties, trees, tree limbs, and power lines were downed by the winds. At [[Stephentown, New York|Stephentown]], a gust of {{convert|58|mph|km/h}} was reported. Ulster County suffered substantial impacts, with large trees being uprooted and striking homes. Across eastern New York State, 25,000 households lost power as a result of the nor'easter.<ref name="Hudson Valley">{{cite web|author=|title=High Wind Event Record Details for New York (2)|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219114|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030524/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219114|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> On the [[North Fork, Suffolk County, New York|North Fork]] of Long Island, in [[Southold, New York|Southold]], a seaside home partially collapsed into the water.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Coastal Flooding Event Record Details for New York|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219146|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030528/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~219146|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
===New England=== In [[Connecticut]], the storm was described as being more significant than anticipated.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|title=Storm on East Coast Batters New England|date=December 25, 1994|publisher=''Victoria Advocate''|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19941225&id=D-ZHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qoAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5944,1340021}}</ref> Gale-force wind gusts, reaching {{convert|70|mph|km/h}}, blew across the state from the northeast and later from the east.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Storm Pounds East Coast|year=1994|publisher=''The Sacramento Bee''|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SB&p_theme=sb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB0DB04DD039D30&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref> Trees, tree limbs, and power lines were downed, causing damage to property and vehicles. The high winds caused widespread power outages, affecting up to 130,000 electric customers. As a result, electric companies sought help from as far as [[Pennsylvania]] and [[Maine]] to restore electricity.<ref name="CT NCDC"/> Bruno Ranniello, a spokesman for [[Northeast Utilities]], reported that "We've had outages in virtually every community."<ref name="NYT"/> In [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]], the nor'easter ripped three barges from their moorings. One of the barges traveled across the [[Long Island Sound]]<ref name="NYT"/> and ran aground near [[Port Jefferson, New York]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|title=Storm Batters New York, Connecticut|year=1994|publisher=''Daily News of Los Angeles''|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LA&p_theme=la&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EF66BE3A53416A7&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM!}}</ref> A man in [[Milford, Connecticut|Milford]] was killed indirectly when a tree that was partially downed by the storm fell on him during an attempt to remove it from a relative's yard. Northeast Utilities, which reported the majority of the power outages, estimated storm damage in the state to be about $6â$8 million (1994 USD; $8.8â$11.8 million 2008 USD).<ref name="CT NCDC">{{cite web|author=|title=High Winds Event Record Details for Connecticut|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194001|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030532/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194001|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
Effects were less severe in [[New Hampshire]] and [[Vermont]]. In southern New Hampshire, a line of thunderstorms produced torrential rainfall, causing flooding on parts of [[New Hampshire Route 13]]. [[Flash flood]]ing of several [[tributary|tributaries]] feeding into the [[Piscataquog River]] was reported.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Flash Flood Event Record Details for New Hampshire|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~216839|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030549/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~216839|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> In [[Maine]], the storm brought high winds and heavy rain.<ref>{{cite news|author=Dave Hanson|title=Rain, Wind to Fade Away by Holiday Southern Maine is Warm but Wet as a Weakening Storm Moves in|year=1994|publisher=''Portland Press Herald''|accessdate=2008-10-22|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ME&p_theme=me&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAE9A02F03FC1F5&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref> Along the coast of southern Maine and New Hampshire, beach erosion was reported. Additionally, minor flooding was reported across the region, as a result of heavy [[surface runoff]] and small [[ice jam]]s.<ref name="weather"/> In [[Rhode Island]], the power outages were the worst since [[Hurricane Bob]] of the [[1991 Atlantic hurricane season]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=R.I. Power Outage Harder to Fix Than in '91|year=1994|publisher=''Boston Globe''|accessdate=2008-10-22|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BG&p_theme=bg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADE122572E89D3&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref> Throughout the state, approximately 40,000 customers were without electric power. As with Massachusetts, downed trees and property damage were widespread. There were many reports of [[roof shingle]]s being blown off roofs and of damage to gutters. In [[Warwick, Rhode Island|Warwick]], several small boats were damaged after being knocked into other boats. The highest reported wind gust in the state was {{convert|74|mph|km/h}} at [[Ashaway, Rhode Island]]. Statewide damage totaled about $5 million.<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=High Winds Event Record Details for Rhode Island|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~231561|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030618/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~231561|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
Massachusetts, particularly [[Cape Cod]] and [[Nantucket]], bore the brunt of the nor'easter. Reportedly, wind gusts approached {{Convert|100|mph|km/h}} on Cape Cod and, offshore, waves reached {{convert|30|ft|m}}.<ref name="met"/> At [[Walpole, Massachusetts|Walpole]], wind gusts peaked at {{convert|88|mph|km/h}}, while on Nantucket gusts of {{convert|84|mph|km/h}} were reported. The winds left 30,000 electric customers without power during the storm, primarily in the eastern part of the state. Power was out for some as long as 48 hours. Property damage was widespread and many trees, signs, and billboards were blown down. A large tent used by the [[New England Patriots]] was ripped and blown off its foundation. The winds also spread a deadly house fire in [[North Attleboro, Massachusetts|North Attleboro]]. Although not directly related to the storm, it caused seven fatalities.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/1994/12/25/killed-fire-fed-winds-north-attleborough/yD1WA2SDhvR1JMT6vfJqAO/story.html|title=7 killed in fire fed by winds in North Attleborough - Metro - The Boston Globe|last=Hart|first=Jordana|author2=Lynda Gorov|date=1994-12-25|work=Boston Globe|accessdate=2014-12-10}}</ref> Because tides were low, little coastal flooding occurred.<ref name="MA"/> Outside the Prudential Tower Center in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], the storm toppled a {{convert|50|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Christmas tree]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|title=Christmas Eve Storm Batters East|publisher=''Los Angeles Times''|accessdate=2008-10-22|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/59631559.html?dids=59631559:59631559&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Dec+25%2C+1994&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Christmas+Eve+Storm+Batters+East&pqatl=google | date=1994-12-25}}</ref> Rainfall of {{convert|2|to|3.5|in|mm}} was recorded throughout the eastern part of the state, contributing to heavy runoff that washed away a {{convert|400|ft|m|adj=on}} section of a highway.<!-- NCDC report says it was Route 107 in Deerfield, although the two are far apart --> Total damage in Massachusetts was estimated at about $5 million.<ref name="MA">{{cite web|author=|title=High Winds Event Record Details for Massachusetts|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2008-10-21|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208983|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520030539/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208983|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Tropical cyclones|United States|Weather}} *[[Timeline of the 1994 Atlantic hurricane season]] *[[1994 Atlantic hurricane season]] *[[Extratropical cyclone]] *[[Subtropical cyclone]] *[[Surface weather analysis]] *[[Hurricane Sandy]] â a tropical cyclone that took on extratropical characteristics shortly before landfall
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{featured article}}

revision.comment: /* Synthesis and reactions */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Proc. Roy. Soc., A â Proc. Roy. Soc. A
revision.text:
[[File:Dodecaborane-3D-balls.png|thumb|dodecaborate ion]] The '''dodecaborate(12)''' anion, [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2-</sup>, has the structure of a regular [[icosahedron]] of boron atoms, with each boron atom being attached to a hydrogen atom. Its symmetry is classified by the [[Point groups in three dimensions|molecular point group]] I<sub>h</sub>.
==Synthesis and reactions== The existence of the dodecaborate(12) anion, [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2-</sup>, was predicted by H. C. Longuet-Higgins and M. de V. Roberts in 1955.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Longuet-Higgins |first1=H.C |last2=Roberts |first2=M. de V. |title=The electronic structure of an icosahedron of boron atoms |journal=Proc. Roy. Soc. A |date=1955 |volume=230 |pages=110â119 |doi=10.1098/rspa.1955.0115}}</ref> Hawthorne and Pitochelli first made it 5 years later, by the reaction of iododecarborane with [[triethylamine]] in benzene solution at 80 Â°C.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pitochelli | first1 = Anthony R. | last2 = Hawthorne | first2 = Frederick M. | year = 1960 | title = The Isolation of Icosahedral B<sub>12</sub>H{{su|b=12|p=2â}} Ion | url = | journal = J. Am. Chem. Soc. | volume = 82 | issue = 12| pages = 3228â3229 | doi = 10.1021/ja01497a069 }}</ref> It is more conveniently prepared in two steps from [[sodium borohydride]]. First the borohydride is converted into a triborate anion using the etherate of [[boron trifluoride]]: : 5 NaBH<sub>4</sub> + BF<sub>3</sub> â 2 NaB<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> + 3 NaF + 2 H<sub>2</sub> Pyrolysis of the triborate gives the twelve boron cluster as the sodium salt.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = H. C. | last2 = Muetterties | first2 = E. L. | year = 1967 | title = Borane Anions | url = | journal = Inorganic Syntheses | volume = 10 | issue = | pages = 81â91 | doi = 10.1002/9780470132418.ch16 | series = Inorganic Syntheses | isbn = 9780470132418 }}</ref> A variety of other synthetic methods have been published.
Salts of the dodecaborate ion are stable in air and do not react with hot aqueous sodium hydroxide or hydrochloric acid. The anion can be electrochemically oxidised to [B<sub>24</sub>H<sub>23</sub>]<sup>3â</sup>.<ref name=Sivaeva002>{{cite journal|last1=Sivaev|first1=Igor B.|last2=Bregadze|first2=Vladimir I.|last3=SjÃ¶berg|first3=Stefan|title=Chemistry of closo-Dodecaborate Anion [B12H12]2-: A Review|journal=Collection of Czechoslovak Chemical Communications|date=2002|volume=67|issue=6|pages=679â727|doi=10.1135/cccc20020679}}</ref>
==Substituted derivatives== Salts of B<sub>12</sub>H{{su|b=12|p=2â}} undergo [[hydroxylation]] with hydrogen peroxide to give salts of [B<sub>12</sub>(OH)<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cesium dodecahydroxy-closo-dodecaborate, Cs<sub>2</sub>[B<sub>12</sub>(OH)<sub>12</sub>]|author1= Lee, Mark W., Jr.|author2=Safronov, Alexander V.|author3=Jalisatgi, Satish S.|author4=Hawthorne, M. Frederick|author-link4=M. Frederick Hawthorne|journal=Inorganic Syntheses|year=2010|volume=35|pages=63â66|doi=10.1002/9780470651568.ch2|series= Inorganic Syntheses|isbn= 9780470651568}}</ref> The hydrogen atoms in the ion [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2-</sup> can be replaced by the halogens with various degrees of substitution. The following numbering scheme is used to identify the products. The first boron atom is numbered 1, then the closest ring of five atoms around it is numbered anticlockwise from 2 to 6. The next ring of boron atoms is started from 7 for the atoms closest to number 2 and 3, and counts anticlockwise to 11. The atom opposite the original is numbered 12. A related derivative is [B<sub>12</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup>. The icosahedron of boron atoms is [[aromatic]] in nature.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
Under kilobar pressure of carbon monoxide [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> reacts to form the carbonyl derivatives [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>11</sub>CO]<sup>â</sup> and the 1,12- and 1,7-isomers of B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>10</sub>(CO)<sub>2</sub>. The para disubstitution at the 1,12 is unusual. In water the dicarbonyls appear to form carboxylic ions: [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>10</sub>(CO)CO<sub>2</sub>H]<sup>â</sup> and [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>10</sub>(CO<sub>2</sub>H)<sub>2</sub>]<sup>2â</sup>.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} <!-- The distribution of water around the dodecaborate anion [B<sub>12</sub> clusters depends on the substituents on boron.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Karki | first1 = Khadga | last2 = Gabel | first2 = Detlef | last3 = Roccatano | first3 = Danilo | year = 2012 | title = Structure and Dynamics of Dodecaborate Clusters in Water | url = | journal = Inorganic Chemistry | volume = 51 | issue = 9| pages = 4894â4896 | doi=10.1021/ic300223z}}</ref> The anion [B<sub>12</sub>H{{su|b=12|p=2â}}] has a negatively charged outer shell due to hydrogen's greater [[electronegativity]]. This negative shell attract the protic termini of water. With substituents like [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>11</sub>NH{{su|b=3|p=â}}], the charge distribution is more positive on the top hydrogens near nitrogen and more negative on the lower hydrogens. As a result of this, the water shell around the molecule is arranged in layers of corresponding charges. --> <!-- This is a theoretical study. -->
== Potential applications == Although derivatives of [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> have not found any practical or commercial applications, the unusual nature of this dianion has attracted repeated investigations.
Compounds based on the ion [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> have been evaluated for [[solvent extraction]] of the [[radioactive]] ions <sup>152</sup>Eu<sup>3+</sup> and <sup>241</sup>Am<sup>3+</sup>.<ref>Bernard, R., Cornu, D., Gruner, B., Dozol, J., Miele, P., & Bonnetet, B. (2002). Synthesis of [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> based extractants and their application for the treatment of nuclear wastes. Journal of Organometallic Chemistry, 83-90.</ref>
[B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup>, [B<sub>12</sub>(OH)<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> and [B<sub>12</sub>(OMe)<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> show promise for use in [[drug delivery]]. They form "closomers," which have been used to make nontargeted high-performance [[MRI contrast agent]]s which are persistent in [[tumor]] tissue.<ref name="[10]">{{cite journal|author1=Bondarev, O.|author2=Khan, A.|author3=Tu, X.|author4=Sevryugina, Y.|author5=Jalisatgi, S.|author6=Hawthorne, M.|year=2013|title=Synthesis of [closo-B12(OH)11NH3]â: A New Heterobifunctional Dodecaborane Scaffold for Drug Delivery Applications|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=135|issue=35|pages=13204â13211|doi=10.1021/ja4069613 }}</ref>
Salts of [B<sub>12</sub>H<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2â</sup> are potential therapeutic agents in cancer treatment. For applications in [[boron neutron capture therapy]] (BNCT), derivatives of closo-dodecaborate increase the specificity of neutron irradiation treatment. Neutron irradiation converts nonradioactive dodecaborate containing <sup>11</sup>B to radioactive <sup>12</sup>B, which upon [[radioactive decay]] emits an [[alpha particle]] near the tumor.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tachikawa | first1 = S. | last2 = Miyoshi | first2 = T. | last3 = Koganei | first3 = H. | last4 = El-Zaria | first4 = M.E. | last5 = Vinas | first5 = C. | last6 = Suzuki | first6 = M. | last7 = Ono | first7 = K. | last8 = Nakamura | first8 = H. | year = 2014 | title = Spermidinium closo-dodecaborate-encapsulating liposomes as efficient boron delivery vehicles for neutron capture therapy | url = | journal = Chemical Communications | volume = 50 | issue = 82| pages = 12325â12328 | doi=10.1039/c4cc04344h}}</ref>

{{about|proposed electricity grid|the electricity company|ElectraNet}}
'''Electranet''' is a proposed [[smart power grid|smart electric grid]] which would allow people to sell electricity into the grid without any artificial caps. It was proposed in an op-ed article [[Al Gore]] wrote in a "My Turn" column for ''[[Newsweek]]'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite news |first=Al |last=Gore |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=My Turn: The Energy Electranet |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/37580 |work=Newsweek |publisher= |year=2006 |accessdate= }}</ref>
Like the internet, which widely distributed information, the Electranet would allow homeowners and small businesses to operate [[microgeneration|small generating]] power facilities and contribute to local and regional energy needs by selling power into the grid at a rate that is determined by free market forces. Like the internet, which led to a surge of productivity, the Electranet's [[distributed generation]] model is hoped to lead to innovative power generation through [[alternative energy|alternative]] sources and lowering [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. Electranet advocates predict that as more people participate in the Electranet, the cost of electricity will continue to go down until it becomes free.
In a 2006 speech to NYU,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyu.edu/community/gore.html |title=Al Gore Gives Policy Address at NYU on Solving the Climate Crisis |accessdate= |work= |publisher= |date=September 18, 2006 }}</ref> Al Gore advocated deploying an Electranet as one way to reduce global warming, as well as reduce the cost of energy, by dropping the barriers to entry for average citizens to actively participate in the business of harnessing and distributing power. Al Gore frequently notes that "a lot of energy is all around us. Instead of having the sun bake us in the summer, why not gather that energy", he asks. "Why not collect from road surfaces, roofs, any painted surfaces and more?"
Al Gore has also said that "once there is a convenient way to sell energy into the grid, not only will homeowners be compelled to hop onto the grid and supply energy, but there will also be a brand new market to develop and then sell all sorts of energy gathering devices and technologies, such as solar paint, solar fabrics, thin films for windows, micro windmills, and more."
Al Gore mentioned the Electranet idea in his congressional [[Global Warming]] Testimony on March 21, 2007.
Electranet advocates predict that just like data on the internet, energy itself, including what is necessary for electric cars, will continue to be more economical as more people get onto the smart grid and supply power, and as more and more efficient technologies are developed for gathering the abundant energy around us. It is reasonable to imagine a day when there is no actual cost for driving, per mile, for energy, because of the abundance of energy coming from the Electranet.
==See also== {{Portal|Energy}} *[[Grid-tied electrical system]] *[[Post scarcity]] *[[Vehicle-to-grid]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Electricity grid modernization|state=expanded}} {{Electricity generation}}
[[Category:Electric power distribution]] [[Category:Electric power transmission systems]] [[Category:Smart grid]]

revision.text:
[[File:BM 90827.jpg|thumb|240px|Kudurru recording the legal wrangles over the land of Takil-ana-iliÅ¡u, who died intestate, in the [[British Museum]].]]
The '''estate of Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u kudurru''' is an ancient [[Mesopotamia]]n white limestone ''narÃ»'', or entitlement stela, dating from the latter part of the [[Kassites|Kassite]] era which gives a history of the litigation concerning a contested inheritance over three generations or more than forty years. It describes a patrimonial redemption, or "lineage claim," and provides a great deal of information concerning inheritance during the [[late Bronze Age]]. It is identified by its [[colophon (publishing)|colophon]], ''asumittu annÄ«tu garbarÃª Å¡alati kanÄ«k dÄ«nim'', âthis stela is a copy of three sealed documents with (royal) edictsâ<ref>''asumittu'', CAD A/2, p 348b.</ref> and records the legal judgments made in three successive reigns of the kings, [[Adad-shuma-iddina|Adad-Å¡uma-iddina]] (ca. 1222â1217 BC), [[Adad-shuma-usur|Adad-Å¡uma-uá¹£ur]] (ca. 1216â1187 BC) and [[Meli-Shipak II|Meli-Å ipak]] (ca. 1186â1172 BC).<ref>{{ cite book | title = Property and the Family in Biblical Law | author = Raymond Westbrook | publisher = Sheffield Academic Press | year = 1991 | pages = 98â99 }}</ref> It is a contemporary text which confirms the sequence of these [[Kassites|Kassite]] monarchs given on the [[Babylonian king list]] and provides the best evidence that the first of these was unlikely to have been merely an [[Assyria]]n appointee during their recent hegemony over [[Babylonia]] by [[Tukulti-Ninurta I]], as his judgments were honored by the later kings.
==The stela==
The [[kudurru]] was excavated from the ruins of the [[Marduk]] temple in [[Babylon]] by [[Hormuzd Rassam]] and his chief foreman Daud Thoma in 1880 and is now in the [[British Museum]] assigned museum reference BM 90827. The text is inscribed on six columns on a two foot high stone block topped by a triangular apex carved with fifteen divine symbols.
The case begins âWhen the house of Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u lapsed for want of an heir in the time of King Adad-Å¡uma-iddina, King Adad-Å¡uma-iddina gave the house (i.e. the estate) of Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u to Ur-Nintinuga, brother of Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u.â<ref>(1) Ã© Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u <sup>lÃº</sup>á¸«al, (2) ''i-na'' lugal Adad-Å¡uma-iddina (3) ''mu-un-tuku-ta il-lik-''[''ma''] (4) lugal Adad-Å¡uma-iddina (5) Ã© Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u [<sup>lÃº</sup>á¸«al] (6) ''a-''[''na''] Ur-Nintinuga (7) Å¡eÅ¡ Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u ''i''[''d-'']''in''.</ref>
===Deities invoked in curses===
As was customary on such monuments, various deities were invoked to curse any party who might dispute the legal decision recorded on the kudurru. These included [[Anu]], [[Enlil]], and [[Enki|Ea]] (evil eye), [[Sin (mythology)|SÃ®n]], [[Shamash|Å amaÅ¡]], [[Adad]] and [[Marduk]] (tearing out the foundation); [[Ningursu]] and [[Bau (goddess)|Bau]] (joyless fate), Å amaÅ¡ and Adad (lawlessness); [[Pap-nigin-gara]] (destruction of the landmark), [[Uras (mythology)|UraÅ¡]] and [[Ninegal]] (evil); [[Kassite deities]] Å uqamuna and Å umalia (humiliation before the king and princes), [[Ishtar|IÅ¡tar]] (defeat); all the named gods (destruction of the name).<ref>{{ cite book | title = Deuteronomium 28 und die adÃª zur Thronfolgeregelung Asarhaddons | author = Hans Ulrich Steymans | publisher = Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht | year = 1996 | pages = 56â57 }}</ref>
===Cast of characters===
The roles and readings of the names of the participants have changed since the first publication of the text and the identifications given here follow Paulus (2007), who argues that the outcome of the case hinges on the performance of the "[[River ordeal]]."<ref>{{ cite journal | title = 'Ein Richter wie Å amaÅ¡' â Zur Rechtsprechung der KassitenkÃ¶nige | author = Susanne Paulus | journal = Zeitschrift fÃ¼r Altorientalische und Biblische Rechtsgeschichte | volume = 13 | year = 2007 | pages = 7â14, 21 }}</ref>
The protagonists:
* Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u, the deceased, a ''barÃ»'' or diviner * Ur-Nintinuga, son of SÄmu, a fellow or "brother" ''barÃ»'' to the deceased
Litigants and witnesses during the reign of Adad-Å¡uma-iddina:
* Kidin-Ninurta, son of [I]luÅ¡[u-, son of the daughter of Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u, first plaintiff, loses case * ZÄqip-Pap[nigara], "brother" of the deceased, second plaintiff, loses case * Ninurta-muÅ¡tÄl, "brother" of the deceased, third plaintiff, loses case * Enlil-zÄkir-Å¡umi, the son of N[a-, ''[[Å¡andabakku]]'' of [[Nippur]], witness * Kudurana, the son of Enlil-[. . . . .], witness * sons of Ami[. . . . . . . . . .], witness
Litigants and witnesses under the reign of Adad-Å¡uma-uá¹£ur:
* Izkur-Ea, the son of Adallalu, the son of a daughter of Bit-Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u, fourth plaintiff, loses case * Enlil-Å¡um-imbi, the son of Daian-Marduk, the ''[[niÅ¡akku]]-''priest of Enlil, and ''Å¡andabakku'' of Nippur, acts on King's instructions * Takil-ana-ilÄ«Å¡u, the son of Ninurta-riá¹£Ã»a, a ''bÄl pÄ«á¸«Äti'', provincial governor, an official sharing the name of the deceased, uncertain role * BÄlÄnu, unwitting purchaser of 10 <small>GUR</small> of the estate, acquired from an unnamed son of the deceased * RÄ«mÅ«tu and TÄbnÅ«tu, the sons of BÄlÄnu, fifth and sixth plaintiffs, compensated following the redemption of the land * AmÄ«l-NabÃ», the King's representative
Litigants and witnesses under the reign of Meli-Å ipak:
* Aá¸«u-dÄrÃ», son of (the house of?) Enlil-kidinnÄ«, seventh plaintiff, complains he was overlooked when young, forcibly seizes the land, and wins his case when he undergoes the [[river ordeal]] * Marduk-kudurrÄ«-uá¹£ur, son of Ur-Nintinuga * NabÃ»-Å¡akin-Å¡umi, uncertain relationship, but links Aá¸«u-dÄrÃ» to the house of Enlil-kidinnÄ« * Enlil-nÄdin-Å¡umu, son of Aá¸«u-dÄrÃ», eighth and last plaintiff, exchanges seizure for compensation after Marduk-kudurrÄ«-uá¹£ur is vindicated by a second river ordeal in Parak-mÄri
==Principal publications==
* {{ cite book | title = BeitrÃ¤ge zur Assyriologie, II | chapter = Babylonische Kudurru-Inschriften | author = C. W. Belser | editor = F. Delitzsch, Paul Haupt | publisher = J. C. Hinrichs | year = 1894 | pages = 187â203 }} âGrenzsteinâ no. 103 * {{ cite book | title = Keilinschriftliche Bibliothek, III | chapter = Inschrift aus der Zeit der KÃ¶nnige RammÃ¢n-Å¡um-iddin, RammÃ¢n-nÃ¢din-aá¸«i, Mili-Siá¸«u | author = F. E. Peiser | editor = K. B. Schrader | publisher = Reuther & Reichard | year = 1892 | pages = 154â163 }} * {{ cite book | title = Babylonian Boundary Stones and Memorial-Tablets in the British Museum | author = L. W. King | year = 1912 | publisher = British Museum }} pp. 7â18, pls. VâXXII * {{ cite book | title = Die babylonischen kudurru (Grenzsteine) als Urkundenform | author = F. X. Steinmetzer | publisher = | year = 1922 }} no. 3 * {{ cite book | title = Die Babylonischen Kudurru-Reliefs: Symbole Mesopotamischer Gottheiten | author = Ursula Seidl | publisher = Academic Press Fribourg | year = 1989 }} no. 12 * {{ cite book | title = Die babylonischen Kudurru-Inschriften von der kassitischen bis zur frÃ¼hneubabylonischen Zeit (AOAT 396) | author = Susanne Paulus | publisher = Ugarit-Verlag | year = 2012 }} (Forthcoming)
==References== {{commons category|Kudurrus of Meli-Shipak II}} {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | ImageFileL1 = Fluoromethane.svg | ImageSizeL1 = 100px | ImageNameL1 = Stick model of fluoromethane | ImageFileR1 = Fluoromethane-3D-vdW.png | ImageSizeR1 = 120px | ImageNameR1 = Spacefill model of fluoromethane | IUPACName = Fluoromethane | OtherNames = Freon 41
Methyl fluoride
Halocarbon 41
Monofluoromethane |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | Abbreviations = R41 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 116838 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/CH3F/c1-2/h1H3 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = NBVXSUQYWXRMNV-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo = 593-53-3 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | PubChem = 11638 | ChemSpiderID = 11148 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | EINECS = 209-796-6 | UNNumber = UN 2454 | KEGG_Ref = {{keggcite|correct|kegg}} | KEGG = C11147 | MeSHName = Fluoromethane | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 28826 | SMILES = FC | InChI = 1/CH3F/c1-2/h1H3 | InChIKey = NBVXSUQYWXRMNV-UHFFFAOYAF | Beilstein = 1730725 | Gmelin = 391}} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = CH3F | MolarMass = 34.03 g/mol | Appearance = Colourless gas with pleasant, ether-like odour at high concentrations. | Density = 1.4397 g/L
0.557 g/cm3 (liquid) at saturation pressure at 25 Â°C | MeltingPtC = -137.8 | MeltingPt_notes = {{GESTIS|ZVG= 490961}} | BoilingPtC = -78.4 | BoilingPt_notes= | Solubility = 1.66 L/kg (2.295 g/L) | VaporPressure = 3.3 MPa }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | EUClass = {{Hazchem F+}} | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = | NFPA-H = 1 | NFPA-F = 4 | NFPA-R = 0 | NFPA-S = | RPhrases = {{R12}} | SPhrases = {{S9}}, {{S16}}, {{S23}}, {{S24/25}}, {{S26}}, {{S28}}, {{S33}}, {{S36/37/39}}, {{S60}} }} | verifiedrevid = 415490902 }} '''Fluoromethane''', also known as '''methyl fluoride''', '''[[Freon]] 41''', '''Halocarbon-41''' and '''HFC-41''', is a non-toxic, liquefiable, and flammable [[gas]] at standard temperature and pressure. It is made of [[carbon]], [[hydrogen]], and [[fluorine]]. The name stems from the fact that it is [[methane]] (CH4) with a fluorine atom substituted for one of the hydrogen atoms. == Composition == The compound is the lowest mass member of the '''hydrofluorocarbon''' (HFC) family, compounds which contain only hydrogen, fluorine, and carbon. These are related to the [[Chlorofluorocarbon]] (CFC)s, but since they do not contain chlorine, were thought not to be destructive to the ozone layer.[http://www.rkm.com.au/HALOCARBONS/fluoromethane.html Fluoromethane CH3F] However, they are still very harmful to the ozone layer, and the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol is an attempt to phase them out.{{cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/explainer-hydrofluorocarbons-saved-the-ozone-layer-so-why-are-we-banning-them-86672|title=Explainer: hydrofluorocarbons saved the ozone layer, so why are we banning them?}} It is used in the manufacture of semiconductor and electronic products. In the presence of an RF field fluoromethane will dissociate into fluoride ions that selectively etch silicon compound films ([[reactive-ion etching]]). Fluoromethane has an agreeable [[ether]]-like odor and is also [[narcotic]] in high concentrations. Fluoromethane is highly flammable and burns in air with evolution of highly toxic [[hydrogen fluoride]]. The flame is colorless, similar to alcohol. The C-F [[bond energy]] is 552 kJ/mol and its length is 0.139 nm (typically 0.14 nm). Its molecular geometry is tetrahedral. Its [[specific heat capacity]] (Cp) is 38.171 JÂ·molâ1Â·Kâ1 at 25 Â°C. The [[Critical point (thermodynamics)|critical point]] of fluoromethane is at 44.9 Â°C (318.1 K) and 6.280 MPa. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Organofluorine chemistry]] == External links == * [http://www.chemblink.com/MSDS/MSDSFiles/593-53-3_Boc%20Gases.pdf MSDS at Chemblink.com]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://encyclopedia.airliquide.com/sds/en/059_AL_EN.pdf Data at Airliquide Encyclopedia]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.chemnet.ru/rus/handbook/ivtan/168.html Thermochemical data at chemnet.ru] * [http://www.chemicalbook.com/ChemicalProductProperty_EN_CB4223265.htm CAS DataBase List METHYL FLUORIDE at ChemicalBook] {{Halomethanes}} {{fluorine compounds}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Fluoroalkanes]] [[Category:Halomethanes]] [[Category:Refrigerants]] [[Category:Gases]]
